title: Darius Leonard feared for his NFL career after concussion symptoms wouldn't go away
text:
CLOSE Join insiders Joel A. Erickson and Jim Ayello as they discuss the Colts upsetting the Kansas City Chiefs 19-13. Clark Wade, Clark.Wade@Indystar.com

INDIANAPOLIS -- After the third week, Darius Leonard was scared. For himself. For his career. But mostly for his family. After missing three weeks, the Indianapolis Colts' all-pro linebacker's concussions "severe" symptoms had not subsided. The headaches, in particular, had lingered much longer than he’d expected.

“The first week, I wasn’t thinking about wife and kids, that stuff,” Darius Leonard said Monday at the Colts practice facility. “I was like OK, ‘I’ve had a concussion before. I’ll get over it.’ Second week, I was like, ‘Ahhh, you know, it’s all right.’ The third week, that’s when I really started thinking, ‘Wait a minute. I got a wife and kid. I’ve had a headache for three weeks now. Will I ever be the same? Do I keep playing?’ I mean you have those thoughts in the back of your head.”

Fortunately for Leonard, he finally was allowed to banish those thoughts early last week when the headaches dissipated and he cleared the NFL’s concussion protocol.

Leonard spoke with members of the Indianapolis media Monday after practice for the first time in several weeks, though it wasn't the first time Colts fans and followers have heard from "The Maniac" during that time.

He's been hyperactive on social media, showering his teammates with love and live tweeting during Colts games. It was the only way he was allowed to show his support without being allowed inside the locker room and on the sidelines for the past two weeks.

And that was among the things Leonard hated most about his prolonged absence -- being separated from his teammates, not being able to rebound with them after a tough loss or celebrate after a hard-fought victory.

But what most frustrated Leonard was the uncertainty that accompanies a severe head injury. Words can hardly express Leonard's frustration at not knowing how to make the pain go away. You can ice a sore ankle, Leonard said. You can massage an aching muscle. But there's nothing to be done for the brain.

He just had to wait. Day after day he woke up and wondered: Do I have a headache? How bad is that headache? Does it hurt less than yesterday? Am I making progress?

What if I go outside? Can I go for a walk with my daughter or will the sun make my head throb?

All the unknowns are what frustrated Leonard. Same for the setbacks. There was a point early on when he thought he could return to practice and at least watch, only to learn that being outside was exacerbating his symptoms.

At that point, the team's medical staff banished him from the facility other than 30-minute intervals to undergo testing. Then he'd retreat back to his house and hope the pain would soon go away. It wasn't until the end of the second week that he was even allowed back at team meetings.

CLOSE Frank Reich says his team had a great week of practice heading into the matchup against the Kansas City Chiefs. Matt Kryger, IndyStar

This is among the many inherent problems with diagnosing and recovering from concussions. They're wildly unpredictable. Symptoms can subside, then return. They can linger for months or disappear in a day. They can even come disguised as something else, which is what happened to Leonard.

Indianapolis Colts outside linebacker Darius Leonard (53) and middle linebacker Anthony Walker (50) defend against Tennessee Titans running back Derrick Henry (22) in the first quarter of their game at Nissan Stadium in Nashville, Tenn., on Sunday, Sept. 15, 2019. (Photo: Matt Kryger/IndyStar)

He remembers when he suffered the concussion. It happened, he said, on either the second or third drive of the Titans game in Week 2. Not long after meeting bulldozer running back Derrick Henry in the hole, he began to feel a little ... off.

The feeling lingered, but he chalked it up to fatigue.

"I thought it was just the heat," Leonard said. "It was hot that day."

It was 93 degrees in Nashville at kickoff, but the heat wasn't Leonard's problem. He just didn't know it yet. He didn't tell his coaches or trainers because, he said, he didn't think there was anything to tell. Conversely, they didn't notice anything wrong with him, nor did the independent certified athletic trainers (ATC spotters) who are in booths at every NFL stadium during every game.

It wasn't until after the game in the locker room that Leonard realized he still didn't feel right.

He's far from the first player that's happened to and certainly won't be the last. In fact, a couple of weeks later, safety Clayton Geathers was diagnosed with a concussion after a game.

"The concussion thing is always a concern," coach Frank Reich said recently. "That’s something you don’t want to mess with. I guess the ones that happen and then you get later are typically the more mild ones because it’s not anything that you notice right away. Then all of a sudden you develop symptoms later and then you go back and think about it – you were in the heat of the moment in the game. I just think that’s what happens. Unfortunately, we have had a couple of those."

Like Geathers, Leonard wasn't diagnosed until after the game and immediately placed in the NFL's concussion protocol.

Making the situation even more confounding for Leonard was that he'd never dealt with anything quite like this before. While he had suffered a diagnosed concussion during college, it was nothing like his most recent experience.

Leonard remembers getting his bell rung, blacking out momentarily and knowing almost immediately he'd likely suffered a concussion.

This was so much different. This one didn't seem nearly as severe, so it bewildered him why he was missing so much time. He's never missed more than one game during a season in his life. He played every game in high school, missed one game in college and missed one during his rookie season last year due to an ankle injury.

To miss three games in a row was a feeling completely foreign to Leonard. He began talking to other people who had suffered concussions, including his brother, fellow linebacker Anthony Walker and backup quarterback Brian Hoyer.

What they told him is what he already knew. Concussions can very in severity, in symptoms and in recovery time. There's no perfect indicator for any of it. And there is no cure.

All those unknowns, Leonard said, that's how the doubt start to creep into his mind. Fortunately for him and for the Colts, his fears -- for his career and his family -- were assuaged when his symptoms finally disappeared last week.

But he'll never forget how challenging the past three weeks have been. The most frustrating of his career, he called them.

“It was definitely tough being away from the team, not being able to go out there and help your brothers out," Leonard said. "It definitely was rough, especially when I couldn’t even be on the sidelines. It was definitely a tough time for me.”
